content: small mouse with a christmas wardrobe the mouse is worked from the head and down you start in the back of the head and work towards the tip of the snout you then pick up stitches to work the ears the head is filled with toy filling and you place safety eyes or embroider eyes you then pick up stitches for the neck and work the body from the neck down the arms and tail is worked last pipe cleaners are places in the body arms and legs and the body is filled with toy filling or scrap-yarn the following garments are included in the wardrobe dress sweater pants hat and scarf these mice are meant to be used decoratively but they can be tempting to use as toys for children this is of course possible but be aware that the clothes are designed to have the best possible fit visually on the mouse and not to be intended for play where the mouse changes wardrobe if you want to use the mouse as a dress-up toy for a child you can knit the wardrobe at a slightly looser gauge additionally if the mouse is intended as a toy for a very young child < 3 years old you need to use embroidered eyes instead of safety eyes due to chocking hazard the pattern has been given level of difficulty medium there are no difficult techniques in the pattern but you will be working in a small scale with thin needles and yarn which adds to the level of difficulty the pattern should be very detailed and there are also plenty of pictures in the instructions to guide you as you knit you do not need to be afraid of high level of difficulty when you knit this pattern but you can be mentally prepared for it to be a bit fiddly the mouse on the front page of the pattern is knit in uldspinneri dansk pelsuld 8/2 100 g = 400 m in the color camel the sweater is knit in rauma garn lamull 50 g = 235 m in the colors l11 natur and l35 mørk rød the hat is knit in rauma lamull in the color l35 mørk rød the pants are knit in nøstebarn 2-tråds merinoull 100 g = 600 m the dress is knit in sandnes sunday 50 g = 235 m
